Description: Northern Indiana Public Service Co. (NIPSCO) signed a settlement agreement in which it has agreed to invest approximately $600 million in pollution control technology to resolve violations of the Clean Air Act. The proposed settlement covers all of NIPSCO's coal fired power plants, located in Chesterton, Michigan City, Wheatfield and Gary, Ind. It will require that NIPSCO spend $9.5 million on environmental mitigation projects and pay a civil penalty of $3.5 million. The state of Indiana has been involved with developing this settlement and is a signatory.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Description: Northern Indiana Public Service Co. agreed to pay $13 million -- consisting of a $3.5 million penalty and $9.5 million in spending on environmental projects -- to Indiana and the federal government to resolve Clean Air Act violations. This was part of a larger $613 million settlement announced by the Justice Department; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/in-northern-indiana-public-service-co

Agency: Office of Federal Contract Compliance Programs

Description: NiSource Inc. and Bay State Gas Company dba Columbia Gas of Massachusetts agreed to set up a fund of $56 million for energy improvements and help for low-income customers in affected areas in settlement of allegations they violated consumer protection and pipeline safety regulations with a 2018 gas pipeline explosion in the Merrimack Valley.

The Commission voted 3-2 to approve the $50,000 settlement, which stemmed from an incident that occurred on Aug. 10, 2006, and was caused by a small leak in a gas pipe, resulting in an explosion and fire at a residence in Mount Pleasant Township, Westmoreland County.

The Pennsylvania Utility Commission ordered Columbia Gas of Pennsylvania to pay a $10,000 civil penalty for alleged violations of the state Public Utility Code and federal regulations on pipeline safety.
Investigation triggered by various, unrelated incidents that promoted review of protocols and reporting practices.
Violations of GPS marking rules following the rupture and ignition of an abandoned gas service line by an excavation contractor.

Failure to follow policies and procedures; failure to conduct periodic odorization tests; failure to maintain records for three years to demonstrate compliance with the rules; failure to conduct leak surveys at least every five years; and failure to take immediate and continuous action on grade one leaks until cleared.
Violations of GPS marking rules following the rupture and ignition of a gas main that resulted in extensive residential property damage.
Violations relating to previously identified pressurization protocols to which the company did not correct.
Violations of GPS marking rules following the rupture and ignition of a gas main that resulted in property damage and injuries.
